natural problem: In right triangle $ABC$, $AB=9$, $BC=13$, and $\angle B = 90^\circ$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ respectively; $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ intersect at point $X$.  Compute the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$.
natural solution: We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); fill(A--E--X--D--cycle,rgb(135,206,250)); fill(B--X--C--cycle,rgb(107,142,35));

draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E); draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); label("$13$",(6.5,0),S); label("$9$",(-2,4.5),W);
draw((-2.7,5.3)--(-2.7,9),EndArrow(TeXHead));draw((-2.7,3.7)--(-2.7,0),EndArrow(TeXHead)); [/asy] Since $D$ and $E$ are midpoints, $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ are medians.

Let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$; we draw median $\overline{AF}$. The medians of a triangle are always concurrent (pass through the same point), so $\overline{AF}$ passes through $X$ as well.

[asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);

draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.

(To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.

We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "(real * real)"
and area :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "snd B = 0"
and h1 : "fst B = 0"
and h2 : "snd A = 0"
and h3 : "fst A = 9"
and h4 : "snd C = 13"
and h5 : "fst C = 12"
and h6 : "D = midpoint A B"
and h7 : "E = midpoint A C"
and h8 : "intersection (line C D) (line B E) = X"
shows  "area A E X D / area B X C = 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In right triangle $ABC$, $AB=9$, $BC=13$, and $\angle B = 90^\circ$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ respectively; $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ intersect at point $X$.  Compute the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); fill(A--E--X--D--cycle,rgb(135,206,250)); fill(B--X--C--cycle,rgb(107,142,35));
 draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E); draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); label("$13$",(6.5,0),S); label("$9$",(-2,4.5),W);
 draw((-2.7,5.3)--(-2.7,9),EndArrow(TeXHead));draw((-2.7,3.7)--(-2.7,0),EndArrow(TeXHead)); [/asy] Since $D$ and $E$ are midpoints, $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ are medians.
 Let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$; we draw median $\overline{AF}$. The medians of a triangle are always concurrent (pass through the same point), so $\overline{AF}$ passes through $X$ as well.
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);
 draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.
 (To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
 Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.
 We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
 Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
 Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "(real * real)"
and area :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "snd B = 0"
and h1 : "fst B = 0"
and h2 : "snd A = 0"
and h3 : "fst A = 9"
and h4 : "snd C = 13"
and h5 : "fst C = 12"
and h6 : "D = midpoint A B"
and h7 : "E = midpoint A C"
and h8 : "intersection (line C D) (line B E) = X"
shows  "area A E X D / area B X C = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given four points, A(9, 0), B(0, 0), C(12, 13), and D which is the midpoint of A and B, and E which is the midpoint of A and C. If point X is the intersection of line CD and line BE, then the ratio of the area of quadrilateral AEXD to the area of triangle BXC is 1.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "('a::euclidean_space) point"
and AB BC :: real
and area_AEXD area_BXC :: real
assumes h0 : "AB = 9"
and h1 : "BC = 13"
and h2 : "angle B A C = pi / 2"
and h3 : "is_midpoint D (A, B)"
and h4 : "is_midpoint E (A, C)"
and h5 : "area_ratio AEXD BXC = (\<lambda> A B C D E X. area AEXD / area BXC)"
and h6 : "intersects CD BE X"
shows  "area_ratio AEXD BXC = 1"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In right triangle $ABC$, $AB=9$, $BC=13$, and $\angle B = 90^\circ$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ respectively; $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ intersect at point $X$.  Compute the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); fill(A--E--X--D--cycle,rgb(135,206,250)); fill(B--X--C--cycle,rgb(107,142,35));
 draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E); draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); label("$13$",(6.5,0),S); label("$9$",(-2,4.5),W);
 draw((-2.7,5.3)--(-2.7,9),EndArrow(TeXHead));draw((-2.7,3.7)--(-2.7,0),EndArrow(TeXHead)); [/asy] Since $D$ and $E$ are midpoints, $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ are medians.
 Let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$; we draw median $\overline{AF}$. The medians of a triangle are always concurrent (pass through the same point), so $\overline{AF}$ passes through $X$ as well.
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);
 draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.
 (To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
 Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.
 We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
 Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
 Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "('a::euclidean_space) point"
and AB BC :: real
and area_AEXD area_BXC :: real
assumes h0 : "AB = 9"
and h1 : "BC = 13"
and h2 : "angle B A C = pi / 2"
and h3 : "is_midpoint D (A, B)"
and h4 : "is_midpoint E (A, C)"
and h5 : "area_ratio AEXD BXC = (\<lambda> A B C D E X. area AEXD / area BXC)"
and h6 : "intersects CD BE X"
shows  "area_ratio AEXD BXC = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a triangle $ABC$, $AB = 9$ and $BC = 13$. The angle $BAC$ is a right angle. Let $D$ and $E$ be the midpoints of $AB$ and $AC$, respectively. Let the line segments $CD$ and $BE$ intersect at point $X$. Find the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final answer is $1$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real * real" and area :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_right_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "dist A B = 9"
and h2 : "dist B C = 13"
and h3 : "D = midpoint A B"
and h4 : "E = midpoint A C"
and h5 : "intersect CD BE X"
shows  "area A E X D / area B X C = 1"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);
 draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.
 (To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
 Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.
 We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
 Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
 Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real * real" and area :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_right_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "dist A B = 9"
and h2 : "dist B C = 13"
and h3 : "D = midpoint A B"
and h4 : "E = midpoint A C"
and h5 : "intersect CD BE X"
shows  "area A E X D / area B X C = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a right triangle ABC, with AB = 9 and BC = 13, let D be the midpoint of AB, E be the midpoint of AC, and X be the point where lines CD and BE intersect. Find the ratio of the area of quadrilateral AEXD to the area of triangle BXC. The final answer is 1.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real * real"
and len_AB len_BC :: real
and area_AEXD area_BXC :: real
assumes h0 : "is_right_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "distance A B = 9"
and h2 : "distance B C = 13"
and h3 : "is_midpoint D A B"
and h4 : "is_midpoint E A C"
and h5 : "intersect D C B E X"
and h6 : "area_AEXD = area_quadrilateral A E X D"
and h7 : "area_BXC = area_triangle B X C"
shows  "area_AEXD / area_BXC = 1"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In right triangle $ABC$, $AB=9$, $BC=13$, and $\angle B = 90^\circ$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ respectively; $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ intersect at point $X$.  Compute the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); fill(A--E--X--D--cycle,rgb(135,206,250)); fill(B--X--C--cycle,rgb(107,142,35));
 draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E); draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); label("$13$",(6.5,0),S); label("$9$",(-2,4.5),W);
 draw((-2.7,5.3)--(-2.7,9),EndArrow(TeXHead));draw((-2.7,3.7)--(-2.7,0),EndArrow(TeXHead)); [/asy] Since $D$ and $E$ are midpoints, $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ are medians.
 Let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$; we draw median $\overline{AF}$. The medians of a triangle are always concurrent (pass through the same point), so $\overline{AF}$ passes through $X$ as well.
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);
 draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.
 (To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
 Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.
 We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
 Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
 Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real * real"
and len_AB len_BC :: real
and area_AEXD area_BXC :: real
assumes h0 : "is_right_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "distance A B = 9"
and h2 : "distance B C = 13"
and h3 : "is_midpoint D A B"
and h4 : "is_midpoint E A C"
and h5 : "intersect D C B E X"
and h6 : "area_AEXD = area_quadrilateral A E X D"
and h7 : "area_BXC = area_triangle B X C"
shows  "area_AEXD / area_BXC = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a right triangle ABC with right angle at B, AB = 9 and BC = 13. Point D is the midpoint of AB, and point E is the midpoint of AC. Line segments DC and BE intersect at point X. Let area_AEXD be the area of quadrilateral AEXD, and area_BXC be the area of triangle BXC. Find the ratio of area_AEXD to area_BXC. The final answer is 1.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle_ABC triangle_BXC quadrilateral_AEXD :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and AB AC BC AD AE CD :: real
and angle_B :: real
assumes h0 : "AB = 9"
and h1 : "BC = 13"
and h2 : "angle_B = 90"
and h3 : "is_right_triangle triangle_ABC AB AC BC angle_B"
and h4 : "is_midpoint D AB AD"
and h5 : "is_midpoint E AC AE"
and h6 : "intersect_at_point CD BE X"
and h7 : "area_ratio quadrilateral_AEXD triangle_BXC = (area quadrilateral_AEXD) / (area triangle_BXC)"
shows  "area_ratio quadrilateral_AEXD triangle_BXC = 1"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In right triangle $ABC$, $AB=9$, $BC=13$, and $\angle B = 90^\circ$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ respectively; $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ intersect at point $X$.  Compute the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); fill(A--E--X--D--cycle,rgb(135,206,250)); fill(B--X--C--cycle,rgb(107,142,35));
 draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E); draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); label("$13$",(6.5,0),S); label("$9$",(-2,4.5),W);
 draw((-2.7,5.3)--(-2.7,9),EndArrow(TeXHead));draw((-2.7,3.7)--(-2.7,0),EndArrow(TeXHead)); [/asy] Since $D$ and $E$ are midpoints, $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ are medians.
 Let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$; we draw median $\overline{AF}$. The medians of a triangle are always concurrent (pass through the same point), so $\overline{AF}$ passes through $X$ as well.
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);
 draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.
 (To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
 Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.
 We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
 Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
 Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle_ABC triangle_BXC quadrilateral_AEXD :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and AB AC BC AD AE CD :: real
and angle_B :: real
assumes h0 : "AB = 9"
and h1 : "BC = 13"
and h2 : "angle_B = 90"
and h3 : "is_right_triangle triangle_ABC AB AC BC angle_B"
and h4 : "is_midpoint D AB AD"
and h5 : "is_midpoint E AC AE"
and h6 : "intersect_at_point CD BE X"
and h7 : "area_ratio quadrilateral_AEXD triangle_BXC = (area quadrilateral_AEXD) / (area triangle_BXC)"
shows  "area_ratio quadrilateral_AEXD triangle_BXC = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In right triangle ABC, where AB = 9, BC = 13, and angle B = 90 degrees, point D is the midpoint of AB, and point E is the midpoint of AC. Lines CD and BE intersect at point X. Let AEXD be a quadrilateral formed by connecting points A, E, X, and D. Find the ratio of the area of quadrilateral AEXD to the area of triangle BXC. The final answer is 1.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real * real"
and AB BC AC AD AE CD BE :: real
and angleB :: real
and areaAEXD areaBXC :: real
assumes h0 : "AB = 9"
and h1 : "BC = 13"
and h2 : "angleB = 90"
and h3 : "is_midpoint D A B"
and h4 : "is_midpoint E A C"
and h5 : "intersect_at CD BE X"
and h6 : "area AEXD = 1 * area BXC"
shows  "area AEXD = area BXC"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In right triangle $ABC$, $AB=9$, $BC=13$, and $\angle B = 90^\circ$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ respectively; $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ intersect at point $X$.  Compute the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); fill(A--E--X--D--cycle,rgb(135,206,250)); fill(B--X--C--cycle,rgb(107,142,35));
 draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E); draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); label("$13$",(6.5,0),S); label("$9$",(-2,4.5),W);
 draw((-2.7,5.3)--(-2.7,9),EndArrow(TeXHead));draw((-2.7,3.7)--(-2.7,0),EndArrow(TeXHead)); [/asy] Since $D$ and $E$ are midpoints, $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ are medians.
 Let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$; we draw median $\overline{AF}$. The medians of a triangle are always concurrent (pass through the same point), so $\overline{AF}$ passes through $X$ as well.
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);
 draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.
 (To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
 Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.
 We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
 Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
 Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real * real"
and AB BC AC AD AE CD BE :: real
and angleB :: real
and areaAEXD areaBXC :: real
assumes h0 : "AB = 9"
and h1 : "BC = 13"
and h2 : "angleB = 90"
and h3 : "is_midpoint D A B"
and h4 : "is_midpoint E A C"
and h5 : "intersect_at CD BE X"
and h6 : "area AEXD = 1 * area BXC"
shows  "area AEXD = area BXC"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In triangle $ABC$, let $AB = 9$ and $BC = 13$. Given that angle $B$ is a right angle, let $D$ be the midpoint of $AB$ and $E$ be the midpoint of $AC$. Let $CD$ and $BE$ intersect at point $X$. If the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ is equal to the area of triangle $BXC$, find the area of each of these regions.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real * real"
and a_AB :: real
and a_BC :: real
and a_CA :: real
and a_BX :: real
and a_CX :: real
and a_DX :: real
and a_EX :: real
assumes h0 : "A \<noteq> B"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> C"
and h2 : "B \<noteq> C"
and h3 : "is_right_triangle A B C"
and h4 : "dist A B = 9"
and h5 : "dist B C = 13"
and h6 : "is_midpoint D A B"
and h7 : "is_midpoint E A C"
and h8 : "is_intersection X (line_segment C D) (line_segment B E)"
shows  "area_quadrilateral A E X D / area_triangle B X C = 1"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In right triangle $ABC$, $AB=9$, $BC=13$, and $\angle B = 90^\circ$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ respectively; $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ intersect at point $X$.  Compute the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); fill(A--E--X--D--cycle,rgb(135,206,250)); fill(B--X--C--cycle,rgb(107,142,35));
 draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E); draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); label("$13$",(6.5,0),S); label("$9$",(-2,4.5),W);
 draw((-2.7,5.3)--(-2.7,9),EndArrow(TeXHead));draw((-2.7,3.7)--(-2.7,0),EndArrow(TeXHead)); [/asy] Since $D$ and $E$ are midpoints, $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ are medians.
 Let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$; we draw median $\overline{AF}$. The medians of a triangle are always concurrent (pass through the same point), so $\overline{AF}$ passes through $X$ as well.
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);
 draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.
 (To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
 Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.
 We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
 Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
 Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real * real"
and a_AB :: real
and a_BC :: real
and a_CA :: real
and a_BX :: real
and a_CX :: real
and a_DX :: real
and a_EX :: real
assumes h0 : "A \<noteq> B"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> C"
and h2 : "B \<noteq> C"
and h3 : "is_right_triangle A B C"
and h4 : "dist A B = 9"
and h5 : "dist B C = 13"
and h6 : "is_midpoint D A B"
and h7 : "is_midpoint E A C"
and h8 : "is_intersection X (line_segment C D) (line_segment B E)"
shows  "area_quadrilateral A E X D / area_triangle B X C = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a right triangle ABC with right angle at C, AB = 9 and BC = 13. Let D and E be the midpoints of AB and AC, respectively. Let X be the intersection of line segments CD and BE. Find the ratio of the area of quadrilateral AEXD to the area of triangle BXC. The final answer is 1.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real^2"
and AB AC BC :: real
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 9"
and h1 : "dist B C = 13"
and h2 : "angle B A C = pi / 2"
and h3 : "D = midpoint A B"
and h4 : "E = midpoint A C"
and h5 : "X = intersection (line C D) (line B E)"
shows  "area_quadrilateral A E X D / area_triangle B X C = 1"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In right triangle $ABC$, $AB=9$, $BC=13$, and $\angle B = 90^\circ$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ respectively; $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ intersect at point $X$.  Compute the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); fill(A--E--X--D--cycle,rgb(135,206,250)); fill(B--X--C--cycle,rgb(107,142,35));
 draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E); draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); label("$13$",(6.5,0),S); label("$9$",(-2,4.5),W);
 draw((-2.7,5.3)--(-2.7,9),EndArrow(TeXHead));draw((-2.7,3.7)--(-2.7,0),EndArrow(TeXHead)); [/asy] Since $D$ and $E$ are midpoints, $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ are medians.
 Let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$; we draw median $\overline{AF}$. The medians of a triangle are always concurrent (pass through the same point), so $\overline{AF}$ passes through $X$ as well.
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);
 draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.
 (To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
 Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.
 We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
 Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
 Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real^2"
and AB AC BC :: real
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 9"
and h1 : "dist B C = 13"
and h2 : "angle B A C = pi / 2"
and h3 : "D = midpoint A B"
and h4 : "E = midpoint A C"
and h5 : "X = intersection (line C D) (line B E)"
shows  "area_quadrilateral A E X D / area_triangle B X C = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a right triangle $\triangle ABC$ with $AB = 9$, $BC = 13$, and $\angle BAC = 90^\circ$. Let $D$ be the midpoint of $AB$, and $E$ be the midpoint of $AC$. Let $X$ be the intersection of lines $CD$ and $BE$. Find the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final answer is 1.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real * real" and B :: "real * real" and C :: "real * real"
and D :: "real * real" and E :: "real * real" and X :: "real * real"
and AB :: real and BC :: real
and area_quad_AEXD :: real and area_tri_BXC :: real
assumes h0 : "AB = 9"
and h1 : "BC = 13"
and h2 : "D = midpoint A B"
and h3 : "E = midpoint A C"
and h4 : "is_intersection X C D B E"
and h5 : "area_quad_AEXD = area A E X D"
and h6 : "area_tri_BXC = area B X C"
shows  "area_quad_AEXD / area_tri_BXC = 1"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In right triangle $ABC$, $AB=9$, $BC=13$, and $\angle B = 90^\circ$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ respectively; $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ intersect at point $X$.  Compute the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); fill(A--E--X--D--cycle,rgb(135,206,250)); fill(B--X--C--cycle,rgb(107,142,35));
 draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E); draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); label("$13$",(6.5,0),S); label("$9$",(-2,4.5),W);
 draw((-2.7,5.3)--(-2.7,9),EndArrow(TeXHead));draw((-2.7,3.7)--(-2.7,0),EndArrow(TeXHead)); [/asy] Since $D$ and $E$ are midpoints, $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ are medians.
 Let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$; we draw median $\overline{AF}$. The medians of a triangle are always concurrent (pass through the same point), so $\overline{AF}$ passes through $X$ as well.
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);
 draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.
 (To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
 Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.
 We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
 Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
 Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real * real" and B :: "real * real" and C :: "real * real"
and D :: "real * real" and E :: "real * real" and X :: "real * real"
and AB :: real and BC :: real
and area_quad_AEXD :: real and area_tri_BXC :: real
assumes h0 : "AB = 9"
and h1 : "BC = 13"
and h2 : "D = midpoint A B"
and h3 : "E = midpoint A C"
and h4 : "is_intersection X C D B E"
and h5 : "area_quad_AEXD = area A E X D"
and h6 : "area_tri_BXC = area B X C"
shows  "area_quad_AEXD / area_tri_BXC = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given points A, B, C, D, E, and X on a plane with the distances AB = 9 units, BC = 13 units. D is the midpoint of AB and E is the midpoint of AC. X is the intersection point of lines CD and BE. The area of quadrilateral AEXD is equal to the area of triangle BXC. What is the ratio of the area of quadrilateral AEXD to the area of triangle BXC? The final answer is 1.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real*real"
and l :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_right_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "distance A B = 9"
and h2 : "distance B C = 13"
and h3 : "D = midpoint A B"
and h4 : "E = midpoint A C"
and h5 : "intersect (line_through C D) (line_through B E) = X"
shows  "area_quadrilateral A E X D / area_triangle B X C = 1"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 In right triangle $ABC$, $AB=9$, $BC=13$, and $\angle B = 90^\circ$.  Points $D$ and $E$ are midpoints of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{AC}$ respectively; $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ intersect at point $X$.  Compute the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$. The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We begin by drawing a diagram: [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); fill(A--E--X--D--cycle,rgb(135,206,250)); fill(B--X--C--cycle,rgb(107,142,35));
 draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E); draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); label("$13$",(6.5,0),S); label("$9$",(-2,4.5),W);
 draw((-2.7,5.3)--(-2.7,9),EndArrow(TeXHead));draw((-2.7,3.7)--(-2.7,0),EndArrow(TeXHead)); [/asy] Since $D$ and $E$ are midpoints, $\overline{CD}$ and $\overline{BE}$ are medians.
 Let $F$ be the midpoint of $\overline{BC}$; we draw median $\overline{AF}$. The medians of a triangle are always concurrent (pass through the same point), so $\overline{AF}$ passes through $X$ as well.
 [asy] pair A,B,C,D,E,X,F; A=(0,9); B=(0,0); C=(13,0); E=(A+C)/2; D=(A+B)/2; X = intersectionpoint(B--E,D--C); label("$X$",X,N); F=(B+C)/2; draw(A--F,dashed); label("$F$",F,S); draw(A--B--C--cycle); draw(C--D); draw(B--E);
 draw(rightanglemark(A,B,C,15)); label("$A$",A,NW); label("$B$",B,SW); label("$C$",C,SE); label("$D$",D,W); label("$E$",E,NE); [/asy] The three medians cut triangle $ABC$ into six smaller triangles. These six smaller triangles all have the same area.
 (To see why, look at $\overline{BC}$ and notice that $\triangle BXF$ and $\triangle CXF$ have the same area since they share an altitude and have equal base lengths, and $\triangle ABF$ and $\triangle ACF$ have the same area for the same reason.
 Thus, $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$ have the same area.
 We can repeat this argument with all three sizes of triangles built off the other two sides $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{AB}$, to see that the six small triangles must all have the same area.) Quadrilateral $AEXD$ is made up of two of these small triangles and triangle $BXC$ is made up of two of these small triangles as well.
 Hence they have the same area (and this will hold true no matter what type of triangle $\triangle ABC$ is).
 Thus, the ratio of the area of quadrilateral $AEXD$ to the area of triangle $BXC$ is $1/1=\boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D E X :: "real*real"
and l :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "is_right_triangle A B C"
and h1 : "distance A B = 9"
and h2 : "distance B C = 13"
and h3 : "D = midpoint A B"
and h4 : "E = midpoint A C"
and h5 : "intersect (line_through C D) (line_through B E) = X"
shows  "area_quadrilateral A E X D / area_triangle B X C = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a right triangle ABC with AB = 9 and BC = 13. Let D be the midpoint of AB and E be the midpoint of AC. If X is the point where the line through C and D intersects the line through B and E, show that the ratio of the area of the quadrilateral AEXD to the area of the triangle BXC is 1.
